reviewText: Frank Ferrante's portrayal of Groucho is a classic of performance art. His current one-man (plus pianist) show practically creates a new Marx Bros. movie around and about the audience as Ferrante/Groucho interacts with audience members as well as pianist James Furmston. This show is an outgrowth of the biographical play "Groucho: A Life in Revue," by Arthur Marx and Robert Fisher, which is presented on the disc.The multimedia musical play takes Groucho from his early vaudeville days through his movie and television careers, and winds up with the wistful and frail man that many of us remember from his final public appearances in the '70s. Ferrante's ability to capture the essence of Groucho at each phase of his life is uncanny, almost eerie (as Arthur Marx admits in one of the disc's few bonus features).The supporting cast is excellent as well. Roy Abramsohn matches Ferrante's finesse as he portrays both Chico and Harpo (something I didn't realize till I checked the cast list on the box)and Marguerite Lowell does a tour de force as ten different women in Groucho's life. This was probably a much more "electric" show seen in person. Most of what Ferrante is seen doing here as the movie Groucho has been transferred to his current one-man show, where it plays like comedic lightning. The presentation on this dvd feels a bit remote and dampened, but that is a constant hazard of filming stage shows. At no time does the show feel grim or depressing, which there was certainly a potential for, given the downturn of Groucho's life and energies in his final years. If the conclusion isn't upbeat, its bittersweetness is a satisfactory compromise.The extra features are tiny but worthwhile: an appearance by Groucno's son Arthur, and home movie footage of the youthful Ferrante performing Marx Bros. sketches with his friends. This program is an excellent overview of the Marx Bros. career as well as an effective "teaser" for Ferrante's one-man show. Groucho was a complicated man, but above all, his stage and movie character was a classic comedy creation. And Ferrante is a benevolent genius for keeping that comic legacy alive.

reviewText: One of the most enjoyable, satisfying biopics I've ever seen, "Groucho: A Life In Revue" is a recorded-live video of a stage play telling the great Groucho Marx's life story.  Equal parts monologue, drama, musical, and pastiche of classic routines both from Marx Brothers shows and Groucho's own solo work, it remains pure theatre, not a hodgepodge, in the sense that there's a recognizable through line: Groucho's seeming inability to tell anyone he loved them.Star Frank Ferrante (who in 2013 was still touring in his own Groucho tribute show) has had a heap of praise for his impersonation of Groucho.  On the surface it looks easy, but to "do" Groucho Marx accurately is a lot harder than it looks.  He wasn't all silly walk and wagging cigar, for one thing (or two things).  Just take a glance at the movies Horsefeathers and Duck Soup; the master's famous speeches, on closer examination, seem frequently sullen and delivered in a monotone!  He didn't "sell" the material on film in quite the broad, cartoony way we remember!  So, how, in this case, do you play both the well-known but still enigmatic Groucho character effectively, and his alter-ego, the lesser known Julius Henry Marx?Frank Ferrante's solution is to go big, but not distorted, go upbeat, but not without irony, and, this being live theatre, he is right to do so.  The show zooms along and is smartly staged, with Ferrante bounding between Groucho's home, backstage, stage, and dressing room with tremendous energy and heart.  Intriguingly, he seems a "cuter" more "upbeat" Groucho, but is no less funny because of it; improving on the original, some have said.I think it's more a case of, in mining for what precisely made Groucho tick, Frank Ferrante decided to make an appealingly exaggerated Groucho Marx rather than an exact duplicate, rather like how Beatles impersonators tend to smile too much; we the audience are enjoying the enjoyer.Ferrante's choice as an actor seems to have been to focus on playing an overriding joy in effrontery for its own sake, and that may indeed have been the soul, the absolute centre of Groucho Marx, both man and icon.  While the real Groucho according to legend was not a perceptibly joyous man, he may have wanted to be, and indeed the character always had some aspect of enviable buoyancy, which may be why Ferrante went so directly for the buoyancy, to keep the characterization simple, carry the show, and, cleverly, address the pain inside by so deliberately pushing so hard for buoyancy?  Perhaps.  I'm no shrink (try as I might!).Co-star Roy Abramsohn is handed the equally daunting task of playing both Chico and Harpo (in separate scenes of course).  As impersonations they are far less accurate than Ferrante's Groucho, but Abramsohn makes up in heart and instant likability whatever he lacks in mimicry.  Best of all, he contributes both harp and piano solos, and this aids both Ferrante in making costume changes (He plays Groucho between the ages of 15-85!) and, it helps the entire show feel like a "lost" Marx Brothers movie, which again works.Speaking of work, the hardest-working performer in the show would have to be Marguerite Lowell playing no less than 10 different women in Groucho's life; co-stars, wives, journalists, etc., each and every one with a different look, voice, and posture.  It is impossible to imagine a more versatile character actress than Ms. Lowell; she's that good.  Her "Daddy" duet with Groucho (in which she sings and dances as the sexy Faye McKenzie) is a particular highlight.Nothing in "Groucho" is overlong, superfluous, or disappointing.  It's commendably short but satisfies in every conceivable way.  A must for Marx Brothers fans, obviously, but still an upbeat, engrossing show even if you didn't know the story or the players.  Best of all, it is definitely rewatchable.Three cheers (NINE cheers really) for Ferrante, Abramsohn, and Lowell!  Hooray, Hooray, Hooray times Three!

reviewText: I was astounded by the performance that burst forth from Frank Ferrante in this DVD. The other 2 players were also impeccable. Admittedly, I am an almost life-long fan of the Marx Bros., and was enthralled, taken back in history, and even teary at the end. Ferrante acts as Groucho at various intervals in his life from Teens to 85. He puts on the make-up as he performs, for goodnessake! Its lovingly written by none other than Grouch's son, Arthur, who first met Ferrante dressed as his father in the street - it was the fright of his life, as you can understand.Fans must own this.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Groucho - a Life in Revue, is really a play filmed about the life of the Marx Brothers...mostly from Groucho's point of reference. It has the main actor...Frank Ferrante age from adult to old guy. With famous lines of Groucho through out. An amazing job. I wish it would play longer so that it didn't have to end. Truly funny and touching too.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Brilliantly written and staged, actually co-written by Groucho's son, Arthur; Ferrante is engaged and exhilirating, though his dancing and "moves" are superior (though sometimes a bit frantic) to his *vocal* imitation - as his voice is a bit high-pitched for the deep baritone of Jules Marx.The "older" Groucho is actually the most impressive.Mr. Abrahmsohn is astonishing as Chico, playing piano; and as Harpo, playing the harp.This fan would have appreciated a bit more detail for that 1941 - 1945 period of no new Marx pictures, leading to a better than expected "return" with A NIGHT IN CASABLANCA. Also, detail about his TV Talk Show guest gig era (when the new generation of fans made him as popular as ever). We all remember hilarious appearances on The Dick Cavett and Bill Cosby shows.(Features an after-show appearance by Arthur Marx!).
summary: Three very talented performers play three Legends + one (4.5*)

reviewText: This contains entertaining snippets of A live on stage performance with a real audience of Ferrante an cohorts presenting snippets of the life and snippets of Ferrante acting like Groucho in performance and at time in private life though possibly still performing. I thoroughly enjoyed and will no doubt get many viewings of it . If he ever comes here to Australia to do this I would go for sure. You'll enjoy it.
summary: YOU BET YOUR LIFE IT'S GOOD!
